description: Established in 1878, this is one of Toronto’s oldest neighborhoods and the largest Chinatown in North America. Here, you can find colorful storefronts, bustling streets, and a variety of restaurants and specialty shops. Visit the quaint teahouses and intriguing herbal stores, as well as browse the clothing stores. When hungry, pop by the steaming noodle houses for some wonton soup, hunt for the famous Peking duck, or go on a dumpling crawl. At night, Chinatown lights up in bright neon red, with lanterns lining the alleys and Chinese music blaring from the karaoke bars. Combine your visit here with a trip to Little Italy and Kensington Market—both within walking distance. – Tripadvisor

reviews.title: Rundown
text: Not a very well maintained area of Toronto with lots of rundown and empty shops. Some shops look like they've been closed for a long time.

reviews.title: Chinatown no more ...
text: Toronto Chinatown on Spadina and Dundas was used to be my favorite place to visit.  Every time I visited Toronto, I always came to Chinatown.  The food was great and lots of selection.  However, this time around August 2023, I came to Chinatown in Toronto and to my surprise and sadness, the Chinatown looked rundown and the atmosphere there seemed to be Not lively and busy anymore.  I talked to my relative living in Toronto and she said more shops and restaurants moved out of Toronto chinatown.

reviews.title: Chinatown, Toronto, Canada
text: You can find many budget-friendly things here. It's also a good place to learn about different traditions in downtown Toronto.

reviews.title: A little rundown
text: Chinatown in Toronto covers a very large area. I walked down the main drag which included a Chinese shopping mall. If I am being honest a lot of the area looks rundown. Area as a very large amounts of restaurants and adjoins the trendy Kensington market area

reviews.title: Great time to be had!
text: So much life in Chinatown, Toronto version!  Lots to check out, lots to eat, lots to experience and yeah, lots to smell at times (especially in the Summer!). On any given day, there’s so many people coming up and down Spadina.  Whether you’re there to enjoy House of Gourmet, a Toronto tradition, maybe shop at Meeplemart, catch a smoothie at What a Bagel!, or shop at many of the merchants, Chinatown Toronto will keep you entertained and engaged!  A must do experience while in Toronto!

reviews.title: Bustling Area
text: Chinatown in Toronto is quite a cool area. There are lots of shops selling all sorts of things. It may be memorabilia, food or restaurants and cafes.
Spadina Avenue is definitely a focal point and where this road meets Dundas it is a big crossing. Watch out for traffic, cyclists and streetcars if you are on foot!

reviews.title: Chaotic but interesting
text: Chinatown, along Spadina and Dundas Streets which are both really busy roads, felt chaotic. However, it was interesting to see the stalls set up along the pavement selling Chinese products and produce.

reviews.title: Another chinatown, similar to many others
text: Chinatown is a collection of many Asian cultures. You can find food and knacks from any of the Asian areas such as Vietnam, Cambodia, China, Japan, Hong Kong, etc.  It is similar to most Chinatowns, which include San Francisco, Los Angeles, and Vancouver.

reviews.title: Ho Hum
text: It's super duper ok and very forgetable but the food was good at the restaurants we went to. you should go so you can tell everyone you went there.

reviews.title: Great place to buy Souvenirs!
text: Great Place to buy Cheap Souvenirs! Most of the souvenirs you find in shops here are the same in other Souvenir shops around Toronto and Montreal but sell the items at 2-3x cheaper!

reviews.title: Lots of stores and food places, cheap souvenirs
text: I was lucky enough to walk through and visit torontos Chinatown, it had a lot of culture and looked like another part of the city, It is the best place to get cheaper souvenirs then you will anywhere else. I had the best tacos and a crepe around the corner from a side street in china town, so it is a cultural melting pot.

reviews.title: Chinatown has changed dramatically - no longer skimpy looking and a drag
text: I love going to Chinatown to buy things. But, I haven't been there for so long.  I was surprised that the Street Car are new and reliable to take it.  TTC Street Car comes very often so I'm not scared to wait for it to come. It is accessible to ride the TTC Street Car and easy to navigate in Chinatown.  You cannot get lost in this place.  You can get anything that you want.  If you're lost then ask anyone for directions as they're very helpful to let you know your directions.

reviews.title: Old School Chinatown, Gritty and Chaotic
text: Chinatown in Toronto is vast, run down, and old school. Lots of restaurants with steaming randomness and ducks hanging in the windows. Old world trading companies mixed in with old and new restaurants, murals, and urban grit. Reminded me of the John Cassavetes movie "The Killing of a Chinese Bookie". Like walking around in a Metrocolor film from the 70s. I went 3 nights in a row with my friend and found something different to eat each night. A fun adventure, but not if you want things polished and neat. This is a level of chaos that is disappearing from our sanitized and over reviewed world.

reviews.title: Food, Murals, and Cheap T-shirts
text: The main street of Chinatown is Spadina Avenue.  There are plenty of Chinese restaurants and a few other Asian eateries.  Impressive murals cover the exterior of some of the buildings and alleys.  There were several stores selling cheap t-shirts and other clothing items.

I combined my visit to Chinatown with nearby Kensington Market and the Art Gallery of Ontario.  There is no Chinatown gate like some other Chinatowns but there are these duo red posts with stylized dragons that form the Chinese word for gate at the streetcar stops on Spadina Avenue.

reviews.title: Chinatown Toronto
text: Easy to find. Not far from the downtown area. Lots of shops and restaurants. Not as nice as Chinatown in San Francisco, but not bad.

reviews.title: Was I missing something?
text: I have been to a few Chinatowns (uk and Europe). I just didnt get it here... no soul, rather messy and unwelcoming to the tourist at least.  It looked quite a poor area, quite dirty.  Many restaurants looked dirty too and the ones that we may have chosen to go in to had only menus in Chinese at the door.  So we decided to move on to another part of the city.  We loved Toronto but not Chinatown.

reviews.title: Fantastic selection
text: Lots of places to eat at and very authentic . Very cheap to eat here . Great if you are on a budget . Most staff are friendly and accomodating .

reviews.title: A shortcut to China
text: The Toronto's Chinatown is an easy way to feel like we are in China. Shops and restaurants are just those in China. Great food in an exciting place.

reviews.title: There is a sense of having entered another world when you enter this area
text: Toronto’s Chinatown is one of the largest Chinatowns in North America. Its  history  dates back all the way to the late 1870s. The initial location was another , but due  to plans for a new Toronto City Hall,  business owners were forced to relocate to the current location. Located at West of Spadina, South of Bloor, this 'town' is a vibrant place to visit. The best way to enjoy Chinatown is simply to explore it on foot, popping into the many stores, herbal remedy shops, cafes, restaurants. Toronto's China Town offers shopping bargains galore, all sorts of markets loaded with varying goods include some of the most exotic of fruits and vegetables and the best of what are real authentic Chinese restaurants . Quite nice place to visit.

reviews.title: Friendly, Clean Chinatown
text: Toronto’s Chinatown features a variety of restaurants and shops similar to other Chinatowns in New York, London, and San Francisco, although smaller.
Toronto’s Chinatown is more of a general Asian melting pot, with a wide variety of Chinese ethnicities, and neighboring countries’ expatriates.

reviews.title: The best experience
text: Very nice place to shop and just to walk around. People are very nice and friendly. If u are visiting toronto make sure u check it out. Its safe.

reviews.title: Nice place to stroll n shop
text: This is a place with restaurants and shops. It’s nice to walk around and compare with other Chinatowns.

reviews.title: Good selection of Chinese restaurants in Chinatown
text: I always like to go to Chinatown because there are a couple of good restaurants with Cantonese yam cha, congee and noodles. Recommended to foodies.

reviews.title: Lovely neighborhood to walk around and eat ramen
text: You don’t need to pay for a tour to enjoy Chinatown, Kensington marketplace, graffiti alley, little Italy and Koreatown. Each area is adjacent to each other and you can walk around an explore on your own. Chinatown was very nice and authenticity Chinese. It didn’t feel like a tourist trap and I enjoyed exploring the neighborhood. I even found a lovey supermarket where I got lots of green tea, Thai curries, fresh fruits and vegetables. There are also lots of restaurants where you can devour bowls of glorious ramen- vegan options available.

reviews.title: Not at all what I expected
text: Having been to many "China Town" areas in many cities I expected something more touristy. Instead it is truly a "China Town" within Toronto. It is a bit grubby, random and disorganised but it has a charm all of its own. With the majority of signs in shops in Chinese characters, and only occasional English, it was limited in how interesting it could be but it was worth a visit especially if you are looking for cheap souvenirs. We visited on the way to Kensington Market which is right next door.

reviews.title: Just like in the Tv shows filmed here
text: The district is very intriguing but was a bit gritty. I was overwhelmed by the choices of shops and restaurants. I felt that I needed greater knowledge before going, as minor language barriers inhibited my experience. The Dumpling House was my choice for steamed dumplings! Cooked fast & hot but not watery. Recommend the red pepper dipping sauce highly! The General Tso’s chicken and the chicken and broccoli had good flavor. Go there when in China town.

reviews.title: It's a small place, not as expected
text: Very disappointed that lots of business do not accept credit card. It is a short sighted way of doing business. It will affect the future development of the business. Also government should crack down on this. Because cash business will affect tax collection.
The whole town is small, not as expected.

reviews.title: Chinatown
text: Everything affotable and location walkinh distance closed to alot recomend felt super safe at anytime to walk around solo

reviews.title: INTERESTING DISTRACTION
text: Typical cultural Chinatown area of a large city. My wife and I passed through whilst touring East Canada and enjoyed the sights and colours all around.

reviews.title: Great place to visit
text: Oh my.
So many different shops to check out and bargains galore to be had.
Lively and colourful. Well worth a visit.

reviews.title: Not as vibrant as other Chinatowns
text: It may be the biggest Chinatown in Canada, but it's not as vibrant and colorful as the other Chinatowns I know. Restaurants and shops are sometimes far from one another. At any rate, it's still the best place to buy your souvenirs and try Chinese food. It's quite accessible. You can take buses, street cars or the subway. I took the subway up to Spadina station and from there transferred to a street car that runs along Spadina where Chinatown is located.

reviews.title: Busy place lots of shops & people
text: Such a busy area. Lots of shops. Lots of restaurants. Lots of people. Favorite thing was lunch at dim sum king. You can’t go wrong with any of the places there.

reviews.title: I had a blast
text: I love to eat very nice and relaxing
And you have a safe trip
And Manny more to come
And a safe welcome
And be carefull
And everyone will  have a great day visiting
And I'm sure everything will be alright
And the hotel will be in good shape
And same with you and I
Have a good day visiting

reviews.title: Nothing special
text: If you would like to have Chinese food there are many Chinese restaurants there. Please note that the expected tips is around 15%. Nice mural painting.

reviews.title: Bigger Chinatown than usual but nothing special
text: Badged as the largest Chinatown in North America it extends along two main routes. As other Chinatowns it is a collection of mainly food stores and restaurants. Note really anything exciting compared to other Chinatowns that I have visited other than larger. Ok but nothing to rave about and Kensington Market which is nearby is a better use of time

reviews.title: Not very interesting
text: We walked through Chinatown on the way from Grafitti Alley to the Art Gallery of Toronto. It was 9:30am on a Sunday morning. There were some food markets with fresh fruit stands on the sidewalk that were fun to look at. Lots of reflexology and massage shops that we walked by. A fair number of restaurants open even at that hour. It wasn’t that colorful or lively of a neighborhood, not very interesting to walk through.

reviews.title: Chinatown
text: There are a lot of shops and restaurants. Nice to walk through but I didn't spend much time here. Not many major things to see or do.

reviews.title: Small Ethnic Neighborhood
text: As we traveled through Toronto, we got to see Chinatown. This neighborhood is a collective of various Asian cultures. The restaurant and business are along the west part of Toronto towards Spadina Avenue. There is really not much to see other than taking in the ambiance of the neighborhood.

reviews.title: Fun day in Chinatown
text: Walking around and seeing all the restaurants and all the shops was exhilarating.  It was cold but it did not matter. There were few shops closed, like the herbal shops. I am not sure if that has anything to do with covid. The Dragon City Mall was pretty much empty and that was on a Saturday. I could tell Chinatown Toronto was a lively place before covid. Hopefully it gets back to normal as we plan to visit again in the future. Make sure to visit Chinatown if you are ever in Toronto.

reviews.title: ~~ Wow ! so clean and friendly ! ~~~
text: I  am so  impressed  and  SHOCK !  the whole area  is  absolutely  so clean and  friendly , very safe to walk around , not like  scuzzy Vancouver China Town  B.C , is between Spadina  / Dundas  West , so many unique shops around , foodie  to shopaholic , you need less few days to enjoy the area   , so many International  cuisine to try , from noodle house to   Chinese , Korean , Japanese  , Vietnamese ,  Dim Sum  , Hardware store , Gift shop , If you  visiting Toronto , must  come down to visit and try those  great food ! Plaiter place is amazing gift shop ! King Noodle restaurant lovely Duck !
